summary: This is a reply memorandum filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys in support of a motion to suppress evidence obtained from a grand jury subpoena issued to the law firm Boies Schiller Flexner LLP. The motion argues the government violated Maxwell's Fourth Amendment, Fifth Amendment, and due process rights by obtaining 90,000 pages of confidential material from her civil case without proper notice. It seeks suppression of all such evidence and dismissal of Counts Five and Six (perjury counts) of her indictment.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, filing a motion to suppress evidence obtained from her civil case deposition materials. She is accused of perjury in Counts Five and Six.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, listed as counsel on the filing and signed the document.

persons.name: Laura A. Menninger
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, listed as counsel on the filing.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, listed as counsel on the filing and signed the certificate of service.

persons.name: Bobbi C. Stemheim
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, listed as counsel on the filing.

persons.name: David Boies
persons.context: Named partner of Boies Schiller Flexner LLP, the law firm that represented Virginia Giuffre in the civil suit against Maxwell. The memo suggests he communicated with the government about Maxwell's depositions.

persons.name: Virginia Giuffre
persons.context: The plaintiff in the civil defamation case (Giuffre v. Maxwell) from which the disputed deposition materials originated.

persons.name: Judge Colleen McMahon
persons.context: Chief Judge of the SDNY who modified the protective order in the Giuffre civil case, allowing the government to subpoena Boies Schiller. The defense alleges the government misled her.

persons.name: Judge Loretta Preska
persons.context: Judge presiding over the unsealing process in the Giuffre v. Maxwell civil case after Judge Sweet's passing.

persons.name: Judge Robert Sweet
persons.context: Former judge presiding over the Giuffre v. Maxwell civil case. He issued a pre-deposition order regarding disclosure of criminal investigation materials.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned as Maxwell's associate and co-subject of the civil suit which was described as a 'proxy prosecution'.

connections.description: Referred to together as subjects of the civil suit which the defense claims Boies Schiller transformed into a 'proxy prosecution'.
Defendant and plaintiff in the underlying civil defamation case (Giuffre v. Maxwell).

The defense alleges collaboration and communication between the law firm and government prosecutors regarding Maxwell's depositions and a potential perjury case, suggesting the firm acted as a state agent.
Maxwell was deposed by attorneys from Boies's firm in the civil case. The defense implies Boies encouraged a government investigation.

events.title: Maxwell's First Deposition
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's deposition was taken in the civil case Giuffre v. Maxwell. The defense claims she testified truthfully, relying on the protective order and unaware of an ongoing criminal investigation.

events.title: Maxwell's Second Deposition
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's second deposition in Giuffre v. Maxwell. Count Six of the indictment alleges perjury in this deposition.

events.title: Meeting Between Boies Schiller and Government
events.description: A meeting between attorneys from Boies Schiller Flexner and government prosecutors. Defense notes show the government contemplated a perjury prosecution and Boies Schiller promised to send 'depositions'.

events.title: Filing of Reply Memorandum
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense files this reply memorandum in support of her motion to suppress evidence and dismiss perjury counts.

events.title: Government Opens Investigation
events.description: The government claims it opened its investigation of Maxwell in 2018, but the defense argues it began earlier, citing the 2016 meeting with Boies Schiller.

locations: One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The government obtained approximately 90,000 pages of confidential material from the law firm Boies Schiller Flexner via a grand jury subpoena. This material came from the civil case Giuffre v. Maxwell.

Maxwell's defense argues the government violated her Fourth Amendment rights by issuing an overbroad subpoena to a third party (her former adversary's law firm) without her knowledge, and violated Martindell and due process by getting the protective order modified without notice to her.

Counts Five and Six of the indictment are perjury counts based on Maxwell's April and July 2016 depositions in the Giuffre civil case. The defense seeks their dismissal as 'fruits' of the unlawful subpoena.
The defense alleges the government and Boies Schiller collaborated, with the law firm potentially acting as a state agent to set a 'perjury trap' for Maxwell during her civil depositions.
The defense claims the government misled Chief Judge McMahon about its contacts with Boies Schiller and the origins of its investigation to secure modification of the protective order.
